Executive Summary

Oiltanking Texas City Marine Terminal 

Risk Management Plan
August 2007 Update

Description of the Facility and Purpose of Submittal

Oiltanking Texas City operates a marine terminal loading/unloading and storage facility that annually stores more than five (5) billion pounds of chemicals including hydrocarbons, specialty polymers, solvents, intermediates, monomers and industrial products. The Oiltanking Texas City Marine Terminal is located approximately (5) miles south of Texas City and is involved in the transportation and distribution of chemicals and products. In accordance with U.S. EPA regulation 40 CFR 68, the U.S. EPA has identified quantities for 140 toxic or flammable substances that require a facility to comply with the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule when unit inventories exceed threshold quantities. The RMP rule requires a facility to report the unit inventory for each RMP substance that exceeds threshold quantities, along with an EPA approved chemical release prevention program. In addition, 40 CFR 68 requires all RMP covered facilities to update its Risk Management Plan (RMPlan) every five (5) years or six (6) months after an RMP reportable incident. The initial submittal of the RMPlan for Oiltanking Texas City was in November 2004.  This submittal serves to update information based on a recent compliance audit and EPA RMP inspection.  Oiltanking Texas City currently holds the following RMP-regulated substances above threshold quantities:

Vinyl Acetate Monomer                            108-05-4                 Toxic                  15,000

Key Offsite Consequence Analysis
40 CFR 68 requires all facilities, subject to the rule, to conduct an offsite consequence analysis to provide information about any potential consequ

ences of an accidental chemical release to the public and state and federal environmental agencies.  Offsite consequence analyses are essential in identifying potential hazards of accidental release.  The offsite consequence analysis (OCA) comprises 2 elements, a worst-case scenario and an alternative release scenario.

Worst Case Scenarios

Offsite consequence analyses for the worst-case scenarios (WCS) were conducted using the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidelines. The RMP sets forth specific criteria that must be incorporated in modeling the worst-case scenarios. The EPA defines a WCS as one that results in the greatest distance from the point of release to a specified endpoint. As defined by the rule, the endpoint for a toxic substance is a specified concentration while for flammables it is a specified overpressure from a vapor cloud explosion (VCE).

The scenarios for the Oiltanking Texas City Marine Terminal were calculated using the RMP Guidance for Offsite Consequence Analysis (EPA 550-B-99-009).  Although numerous controls are in place to prevent chemical releases and manage such consequences should an incident occur, no credit for active or passive mitigation measures was taken into account in evaluating these scenarios.

The WCS for vinyl acetate monomer (VAM) is the total failure of a 3,000,000-gal tank, which would lead to the release of 23,500,000 lbs of VAM.  Based on the release rate and VAM characteristics, the distance to the toxic endpoint is 25 miles.  This includes a population of approximately 550,000.

The WCS for ethylenediamine (EDA) is the total failure of a 210,000-gal tank, which would lead to the release of 1,593,060 lbs of EDA.  Based on the release rate and EDA characteristics, the distance to the toxic endpoint is 8.1 miles (less than that for VAM).  This includes a population of approximately 69,000.

Alternative Release Scenarios

Alternative Release Scenarios (ARS) assess the potential

hazards that are more realistic than worst-case scenarios and are designed to assist in the development of emergency response plans.  The RMP Guidelines for Offsite Consequence Analysis were used in modeling the alternative release scenarios.  As required, an alternative release scenario was created for toxics. This scenario was calculated using the RMP Guidelines for Offsite Consequence Analysis.  Although numerous controls are in place to prevent chemical releases and manage such consequences should an incident occur, no credit for active or passive mitigation measures was taken into account in evaluating these scenarios.

The ARS for vinyl acetate monomer (VAM) is a pipe leak in which the contents in a 540-foot section of 6-inch diameter pipe were all released.  This would lead to the release of 6,180 lbs of VAM.  Based on the release rate and VAM characteristics, the distance to the toxic endpoint is 0.3 miles.  This radius only includes the Oiltanking Texas City Marine Terminal and does not include any populated locations.

The ARS for ethylenediamine (EDA) is a pipe leak in which the contents in a 540-foot section of 6-inch diameter pipe were all released.  This would lead to the release of 6,017 lbs of EDA.  Based on the release rate and VAM characteristics, the distance to the toxic endpoint is 0.2 miles (less than that for VAM).  This radius only includes the Oiltanking Texas City Marine Terminal and does not include any populated locations.


Five- Year Accident History

Oiltanking Texas City, in the past five (5) years, has not incurred any chemical releases that resulted in any known onsite or offsite deaths, injuries, significant damage, evacuations or sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage.   


Accidental Release Prevention Policies

The plans for evacuation and accounting for personnel after an evacuation at Oiltanking Texas City are located onsite for all personnel to review.

If a release occurs, arrangements are described in

the Emergency Response Plan for notification of local emergency response agencies and the public.

Oiltanking Texas City is committed to operate and maintain its facility in a safe and environmentally friendly manner. Oiltanking Texas City complies with the rules and regulations set forth by the U.S. EPA Risk Management Plan to ensure the safety of employees and public surroundings.

Oiltanking Texas City designed its accident prevention program to comply with the EPA RMP rule.  Oiltanking Texas City incorporates elements addressing the following:

* Equipment Design ¿ Vessels (including shipping containers) and other process equipment are designed according to recognized industry standards and/or governmental requirements.

* Process Safety Information ¿ Chemical hazard, process technology, and equipment information is documented, maintained up-to-date, and available to operating personnel.

* Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) ¿ PHAs are conducted every three (3) years to identify major process hazard scenarios and to recommend corrective action(s) needed to prevent their occurrence.

* Episodic Risk Management ¿ Periodic reviews are conducted to identify hazards which could have significant community impact and to recommend corrective action(s) needed to prevent their occurrence.  These reviews utilize advanced quantitative risk assessment techniques.

* Operational Safety Standards ¿ Design requirements for active and passive mitigation controls used to prevent major process hazards are documented in operational safety standards.

* Operating Procedures ¿ Operating procedures provide detail on how to safely operate a process and are maintained up-to-date.

* Operator Training/Certification Program ¿ The plant has a training and testing program, which provides operators with the proper skills and knowledge prior to allowing them to independently operate a process.

* Technical Staff Training and Support ¿ Trained technical staff employees are available 24 hours a day

gement system to prevent accidental chemical releases.  Oiltanking Texas City and its employees are committed to the standards that these management systems set, and have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that they are meeting their own high standards for accident prevention.


Emergency Response Program

Oiltanking Texas City maintains a written emergency response program to protect worker and public safety, as well as the environment.  The program consists of procedures for responding to releases of hazardous substances, including fire or explosion and is updated when necessary based on modifications made to the facility.

The procedures address all aspects of emergency response including:

* Proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures.
* Evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation.
* Notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs.
* Post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.
* Inspecting, testing, maintaining, and using emergency response equipment.

Oiltanking Texas City maintains a trained emergency squad to handle fire, explosions, toxic vapor releases, spills, and medical emergencies.  The facility trains and drills with local emergency responders to enhance their skills and tactics for responding to an accidental chemical release.  Critiques are held on drills and actual events.  The emergency response program provides the essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  Detailed emergency response plans are developed and coordinated with the Galveston County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).


Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Oiltanking Texas City continually strives to improve its safety-related systems.  Its policies and procedures provide the most efficient means to minimize environmental impacts onsite and to the public.  Oiltanking Texas City also continues to improv

e by implementing an incident investigation database to monitor potential risks of future incidents.  These improvements, along with monthly reviews of current safety protocols, reduce the risk of future incidents.
